stories.text:
My long-time ISP and VOIP provider is turning off my DSL circuit next month, and I've been in the process of migrating to a new ISP and need a new VOIP provider.

There is a vast array of VOIP providers with many different service plans, features and pricing structures.

Since this isn't an area where I'm an SME, I've searched around quite a bit, but am a little overwhelmed by the number and type of services available.

At a minimum, I need to be able to make and answer actual phone calls with my existing VOIP number and forward incoming calls to my (also existing) mobile number.

The various "standard" features:

1. Call forwarding after $X rings

2. Access/use via mobile device

3. Inbound/outbound international (I'm in the US) calls (both when I'm in the US and outside of it.

Those would be useful, but all I really need is call forwarding and calling worldwide from inside the US.

It would also be useful to be able to manage my own VOIP-enabled desk/cordless phone (perhaps through something like Asterisk[0]), but that's not strictly necessary.

Ideally, it would be great if it were free, but that's not strictly necessary either. I started looking at Google Voice (which doesn't provide all the features listed above, but as I said, I only need inbound/outbound calling and call-forwarding).

That said, I try to stay as far away from Google as possible whenever I can.

What sorts of experience have other folks had with various VOIP providers?

What sorts of provider/feature recommendations would you make toward enhancing privacy and security for VOIP services?

[0] https://www.asterisk.org/

Edit: Added the missing link.
